results.title: Petersen
results.brief_description: Petersen is an electrician and former football star who yearns to be a teacher, so he attends university. But it’s the female professors, students, and all the women he comes in contact with who learn a thing or two from him. Stars Jack Thompson, Jacki Weaver and Wendy Hughes.

results.title: Peterborough Cathedral
results.brief_description: Scarred by invasion and fire, the Cathedral has passed through architectual periods og great interest. From the west door there is an unbroken vista to the alter and the lofty choir. In the 15th Century eastern chapel with its fine fan-vaulted roof, is the famous Monk’s stone.

results.title: Peter Yeldham's Captain James Cook. Part two
results.creator_credit: Revcom Television, ABC-TV (Australia), Ray Alchin and Lawrence Gordon Clark
results.brief_description: In the late 1700’s King George 111 of England orders an ambitious expedition to the Pacific Ocean to observe an eclipse of the sun and to seek the mythical Southern Continent. James Cook (Keith Michell), a relatively unknown petty officer, is controversially appointed as commander, choosing an unlikely collier to carry him and his men into dangerous and unknown waters. After sailing to Tahiti, where the eclipse proves disappointing, Cook proceeds to chart the coasts of New Zealand and Australia beginning a glorious adventure spanning the oceans of the world. Part two concludes the saga of one of history’s great ocean explorers. Cast includes Keith Michell, Carol Drinkwater, Fernando Ray and Jaques Penot. Based on the novel by Peter Yeldham.

results.title: Peter Weir: short film collection
results.creator_credit: ScreenSound Australia, Film Australia and Peter Weir
results.brief_description: Three to go: Michael: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Michael has to make decisions in the complex but permissive world of today. His friends have followed a relatively straight and narrow path of conformity. Michael has more or less taken this course, but knows that other ways exist. He is prepared to listen to the prophets of change and revolution and is taken on an excursion into the world of the young radical. In which world does Michael belong?. Features Grahame Bond. Homesdale: Mr. Malfry is having his first vacation at Homesdale - an expensive, private guest house on a remote island near Sydney. The guests are encouraged to live out their fantasies, and have accustomed themselves to the atmosphere with ease. Mr. Malfry emerges as the odd man out and his efforts to mix in are unsuccessful, until a solution occurs to him. Treading a perilous line between horror and farce, “Homesdale” deliberately eschews plot and character development. Isolation, eccentricity and mad authority are the ingredients for this loosely woven depiction of life in a mysterious sanatorium. Three directions in Australian Pop Music: Australian Colour Diary 43: Three songs performed by three Australian artists from 1971; Wendy Saddington and Teardrop; The Captain Matchbox Whoopee Band and Indelible Murtceps. Long hair, mime and psychodelic lighting are part of the experience! Incredible Floridas: This is composer Richard Meale’s homage to the French poet, Arthur Rimbaud. Scored for woodwind, percussion and string instruments, it was written for the “Fires of London” and their conductor, Peter Maxwell Davies, and premiered in London in 1971 to an enthusiastic reception. Richard Meale is a leader in contemporary music in Australia. Released on DVD by Umbrella Entertainment and The AV Channel. Also available on VHS/16mm [010905], [300809], [005261].

results.title: Peter Ustinov reads the orchestra
results.creator_credit: Mark Rubin Productions and Mark Rubin
results.brief_description: This video version of the award-winning recording and book featuring The Toronto Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Walter Babiak, is a highly engaging way to introduce children to classical music and the instruments of the orchestra. It explains the process of composition and the basic musical concepts of melody, harmony, rhythm, tempo, dynamics and tone colour. It then describes the four main families of orchestral instruments and each of their individual members. It concludes with the role of the conductor, bringing music and musicians together in a grand concert finale. There are excerpts from 22 of the great classics, such as Tchaikovsky’s Nutcracker Suite and Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 5. Peter Ustinov’s narration, bursting with warmth and humour, and Alan Daniel’s colourful drawings of the musicians and their instruments make “The Orchestra” thoroughly entertaining and informative viewing.

results.title: Peter Ustinov's Leningrad
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns and John McGreevy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
Presents Peter Ustinov’s personal view of Leningrad. He briefly relates the city’s history, showing many of the buildings - St. Peter and St. Paul Cathedral, the Imperial Winter Palace, St. Isaac’s Cathedral, amongst many others. He discusses many aspects of the arts, literature, music ballet and drama of Leningrad.

results.title: Peter Sculthorpe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Peter Sculthorpe, Australia’s best-known contemporary composer, discusses his personal philosophy and the influences which have shaped his creative development. Sculthorpe studied at the Melbourne University Conservatorium of Music and at Oxford University. His “Sonatina for Piano” was performed at the International Society of Contemporary Music Festival in Baden-Baden in 1955 and he went on to receive international recognition with the success of his Sun Music series. Throughout his career, Sculthorpe has drawn on a diversity of cultural influences in his quest to develop uniquely Australian music. He has composed for film, television, theatre and opera as well as the concert platform, and enjoys the status of elder statesman among contemporary Australian composers. A performance of his work “Kakadu” in 1989 was a rallying point for Australian conservationists and since then Sculthorpe has used his music to promote environmental causes. Research and interview: James Murdoch.
